How do you use the Tag System?
description:
The primary purpose of tags is filtering stories out of your feed (even without an account) to improve the site’s signal : noise ratio, though the number of applied filters seems surprisingly low. Filtering even applies when using the site as a mailing list or via rss combinations like https://lobste.rs/t/programming,audio.rss .)

Other uses include looking stories up by tag, category or groups and refining search results e.g. tag:ruby sqlite (especially relevant for concatenative whose languages’ generic names make for poor searches.)

Sometimes lacking a good tag makes posting a story difficult e.g. due to a vague title. Personally, I face this issue with gofai techniques, often posting them under the implementation family lisp.

What other browsing/research workflows do you have or wish for?

To paraphrase @pushcx : tags should be useful, easy for submitters to choose, things people want to follow on rss, discuss or ignore. If fewer tags are easier to apply and fit our interests better, great. If python2->3 went even worse and both remained, we’d carry on with separate tags so the communities could ignore each other.

The guiding light is increasing users’ signal, not taxonomic purity, so a whole language family APL is fine alone while in the python2 : python3. The tags should match cohesive communities not stretch across them. Now, there is some historical baggage in tag choice, resulting in (recently) unused tags. Some example thoughts:

  • dragonflybsd (mostly tagged in conjunction with other bsds! Yet many filter it!)
  • immumos (only a few stories per year, could be unix - are the filterers unix “subscribers”?)
  • js and nodejs (I don’t use js and can’t judge, but this seems odd - I wonder whether front-end and backend/server would be useful, letting people e.g. ignore python servers. Filtering combinators e.g. js+backend would be too niche and require technical changes, outside of scope.)
  • objectivec (I don’t know it, but don’t think it fits under c/c++. It’d be “easier” if we had a c-alternative tag for hare, odin, d, objectivec. It seems like people would block filter those. But at what point would e.g. zig lovers want to not read about the others? What kind of curiosity-flows do people have there?)
  • plt (dumpling grounds, e.g. logic programming sometimes makes it there or under ai… Similarly, paradigms without a family tag like Forth often go to plt. “Practices” type advice also often goes here. To a large extent, it means “no tag”
  • clojure (I actually only learned this existed a few months ago, I’d tagged multiple clojure stories with lisp…)

Aggregate queries can partially disambiguate these (e.g. comparing the popularity of rss combinator combinations for different bsds, whether visitors of one bsd filter others etc.)

I want to improve tagging benefits and accuracy. I’m collecting ideas to query around and refit them to current use.
description_plain:
The primary purpose of tags is [filtering](https://lobste.rs/filters) stories out of your feed (even without an account) to improve the site's signal : noise ratio, though the number of applied filters seems surprisingly low. Filtering even applies when using the site as a [mailing list](https://lobste.rs/s/jg3eet) or via rss combinations like https://lobste.rs/t/programming,audio.rss .)

Other uses include looking stories up [by tag](https://lobste.rs/t/elixir), category or [groups](https://lobste.rs/t/javascript,go) and refining search results e.g. `tag:ruby sqlite` (especially relevant for [concatenative](https://lobste.rs/s/7q3ntz/tag_proposal_concatenative) whose languages' generic names make for poor searches.)

Sometimes lacking a good tag makes posting a story [difficult](https://lobste.rs/s/xiwy8s/tag_proposal_gleam#c_dmxwun) e.g. due to a vague title. Personally, I face this issue with gofai techniques, often posting them under the implementation family lisp.

What other browsing/research workflows do you have or wish for?

-----

To paraphrase @pushcx : tags should be useful, easy for submitters to choose, things people want to follow on rss, discuss or ignore. If fewer tags are easier to apply and fit our interests better, great. If python2->3 went even worse and both remained, we'd carry on with separate tags so the communities could ignore each other.

The guiding light is increasing users' signal, not taxonomic purity, so a whole language family APL is fine alone while in the python2 : python3. The tags should match cohesive communities not stretch across them. Now, there is some historical baggage in tag choice, resulting in (recently) unused tags. Some example thoughts:

- dragonflybsd (mostly tagged in conjunction with other bsds! Yet many filter it!)
- immumos (only a few stories per year, could be unix - are the filterers unix "subscribers"?)
- js and nodejs (I don't use js and can't judge, but this seems odd - I wonder whether front-end and backend/server would be useful, letting people e.g. ignore python servers. Filtering combinators e.g. js+backend would be too niche and require technical changes, outside of scope.)
- objectivec (I don't know it, but don't think it fits under c/c++. It'd be "easier" if we had a c-alternative tag for hare, odin, d, objectivec. It seems like people would block filter those. But at what point would e.g. zig lovers want to not read about the others? What kind of curiosity-flows do people have there?)
- plt (dumpling grounds, e.g. logic programming sometimes makes it there or under ai... Similarly, paradigms without a family tag like Forth often go to plt. "Practices" type advice also often goes here. To a large extent, it means "no tag"
- clojure (I actually only learned this existed a few months ago, I'd tagged multiple clojure stories with lisp...)

Aggregate [queries](https://lobste.rs/about#queries) can partially disambiguate these (e.g. comparing the popularity of rss combinator combinations for different bsds, whether visitors of one bsd filter others etc.)

----

I want to improve tagging benefits and accuracy. I'm collecting ideas to query around and refit them to current use.

Tag Proposal: concatenative
description:
Category: Languages Name: concatenative Description: stackbased languages like Forth, Factor, Joy

A tag would be really useful, because these languages have unhelpful names like forth, factor, joy so most search hits are… not relevant. A tag would let us even find these stories and disambiguate them in the feed!

Some recent stories:

  • https://lobste.rs/s/s75rfx/sapf_forth_like_language_for_audio
  • https://lobste.rs/s/ejlu9h/moving_forth_series_on_writing_forth
  • https://lobste.rs/s/p5gpeq/original_chipwits_forth_code_open

  • https://lobste.rs/s/n9vtqo/my_history_with_forth_stack_machines_2010
  • https://lobste.rs/s/ckhnig/forth_is_best_programming_language_for
  • https://lobste.rs/s/zolh4m/macro_forth_forth_implemented_compile
  • https://lobste.rs/s/iyncoq/bytecode_interpreters_for_tiny
  • https://lobste.rs/s/j23p0w/starting_forth
  • https://lobste.rs/s/ruynmz/getting_started_with_duskos
  • https://lobste.rs/s/8doqmk/meow5_concatenative_assembly
  • https://lobste.rs/s/ajcrtw/forth_bitcoin_miner_for_pc_game_boy
  • https://lobste.rs/s/tjrbzv/thinking_forth_language_philosophy_for
  • https://lobste.rs/s/nvtnqv/retro_modern_pragmatic_forth

Some old:

  • https://lobste.rs/s/p5tuau/milliforth_forth_422_bytes_smallest_real
  • https://lobste.rs/s/shvfr8/zen_forth
  • https://lobste.rs/s/2yhcjo/space_related_applications_forth_1998
  • https://lobste.rs/s/mul1cs/conway_s_game_life_apl_forth
  • https://lobste.rs/s/v2rnti/low_fat_computing_1998
  • https://lobste.rs/s/e9f2qe/forth_language_language_design
  • https://lobste.rs/s/zeyn75/bootstrapping_forth_40_lines_lua_code
  • https://lobste.rs/s/ea86a2/dave_s_forth_talk_2023
  • https://lobste.rs/s/doghrl/what_hell_is_forth
  • https://lobste.rs/s/mcgvak/frustration_escaping_turing_tar_pit_with
  • https://lobste.rs/s/4piifs/1x_forth_by_charles_moore_4_13_99
  • https://lobste.rs/s/axqvhe/beginner_s_guide_forth_2001
  • https://lobste.rs/s/cfwnku/moonforth_tinker_with_interactive_dcpu
  • https://lobste.rs/s/z2zt99/my_history_with_forth_stack_machines
  • https://lobste.rs/s/ncxkzy/forth_hacker_s_language
  • https://lobste.rs/s/kj6dpe/thoughtful_programming_forth
  • https://lobste.rs/s/h42ayv/recommended_reading_starting_forth

A prior proposal was made 4 years ago: https://lobste.rs/s/ijpdeu/tag_proposal_forth
